@techsavvyed I feel like some of the nuance was there in her writing but things get oversimplified when spread.
@techsavvyed But I feel like they all get lobbed into the same category.
@techsavvyed Affirmation is about identity, praise is meant to boost performance, feedback is information on performance.
@techsavvyed I think there is so much nuance to this, though. Feedback, praise, affirmation all seem different.
@techsavvyed @alfiekohn Or feedback is better than praise, period.

@tompanarese Also wondering if there would be a difference in the results in comparing the grade levels.
@tompanarese It would be interesting to see an overall study of teacher-selected versus student-selected. Curious which one would be harder.
@FeministsCreate @OP_ASU Thanks for the kind words!
@classroom_tech But the self-selection of challenge level seems to be more about self-efficacy than motivation.
@classroom_tech I find that self-selection of content, topic, and approach are all like that.
@classroom_tech But I couldn't find any research on it. Most of the research seemed to assume teacher selection.
@classroom_tech I was hoping to find research on whether self-selecting or teacher-selection tends to be higher challenge.
@classroom_tech I'm thinking both. Exploring the notion of students self-selecting task, scaffolding, difficulty, etc.
When students self-select the difficulty of a task, are they more likely to choose a more challenging task or an easier task?

@NoApp4Pedagogy Thanks. Feel the same way about you and your work.
@NoApp4Pedagogy Do you see it more as a paradigm, an issue of motivation, or an issue of self-efficacy?
@NoApp4Pedagogy I'm saying that feedback (pros and cons, focus on style, etc.) works best locally rather than globally.
@NoApp4Pedagogy I could see that. And, I'm a fan of that. I'm just saying that I see feedback as being related to style and being critical.
@NoApp4Pedagogy One of the things I have a hard time with is when teachers use the comment section of blogs to approach feedback / style
@NoApp4Pedagogy On the other hand, I'm going to have a small team working with me to push back on style, organization, etc.
@NoApp4Pedagogy Exactly. I think of myself as an author. My final work is going to be sent to the world to discuss ideas.
@NoApp4Pedagogy I see the opposite trend. Trusted relationships create a space where honest feedback happens.
@NoApp4Pedagogy But I see power in sending a final work to the world and generating a discussion on ideas.
@NoApp4Pedagogy I guess I see it like this: feedback (especially on the craft of writing) is pre-published, local, contextual.
@NoApp4Pedagogy I see discussion and commentary as being global, working well with a larger audience.
@NoApp4Pedagogy I see feedback as contextual and based on trusted relationships. It should be local.
@NoApp4Pedagogy I think you have two really different things you're going for.
@NoApp4Pedagogy Absolutely. I just think it's a harder thing to pull off
@tyleramidon @Bendirksen @mdboer77 @PolandValerie @LSTEK24 @Bklo1331 Thanks, Tyler!
@NoApp4Pedagogy So, while global collaborative groups are still really popular, you have kids publishing to groups on sports, Minecraft, etc
@NoApp4Pedagogy However, topical/themed groups were a part of what we built with @mywriteabout. We really wanted to go for interest-driven.
@NoApp4Pedagogy @littlemacf650 @DavidBillikopf @QuadBlogging Haven't used it.
@SRyan3rdgrade @EdTechSpec I'm now teaching college, so it probably isn't a great fit. But they are thriving with blogging, too #caedchat
@NoApp4Pedagogy I think many of them won't . . . and that's fine. However, when they do, it's pretty awesome #caedchat
I tried having students treat blogging like actual bloggers (topical, thematic, fun) rather than digital journals and they thrived #caedchat
@NoApp4Pedagogy I think the ultimate test of success is whether or not they continue to blog after leaving your class #caedchat
